item.title: The ICEmen Killeth
item.description: So long as ICE agents, in their zeal to fulfill deportation quotas, targeted Hispanics or people of color, most white Americans did not fear for their safety, even if they deplored such tactics. But the murder by federal officers of two white US citizens at close range changes that, and the public backlash won’t fade soon.

item.title: America’s Mad Emperor
item.description: Every "logical" explanation that has been applied to US President Donald Trump's unhinged behavior over the years has proven inadequate. At this point, detractors and former supporters alike are recognizing that Trump's words and deeds can be explained by only one thing: mental derangement.

item.title: Penicillin and American Power
item.description: Technological leadership is often framed as a matter of singular breakthroughs rather than institutional capacity. But the rapid development of penicillin during World War II shows that coordinated public leadership, strong research institutions, and a dynamic private sector produce results no other innovation system can achieve.

item.title: Our Tariff-Era Dollar, Your Problem
item.description: The greenback’s effective depreciation on the trade side and its continued stability on the financial side will likely not last forever, at which point the US economy could be forced into a painful rebalancing. But until that day arrives, non-US economies should not assume that a weaker dollar will deliver the usual relief.

item.title: The Impact of Trump’s Tariffs on Latin America
item.description: The Latin American and Caribbean region has weathered the increase in US import tariffs relatively well, although certain countries and sectors have been more affected than others. But the more fraught global trade environment has underscored the need to deepen ties with regional and extra-regional partners.

item.title: The Middle-Power Dilemma
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney's call for the rest of the world to join forces in managing a new era of economic and geopolitical turmoil will certainly resonate with national leaders worldwide. But the path to unity among middle powers is fraught, because interests within such a broad grouping rarely align.

item.title: When Misinformation Kills
item.description: Disregard for scientific evidence by opponents of vaccination, led by US Secretary of Health and Human Services Robert F. Kennedy Jr., is producing exactly the harms experts predicted: disease outbreaks, preventable deaths, and the reversal of decades of progress in public health. The consequences could become truly catastrophic.

item.title: A United Front to Tame Trump
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s foreign policy rests on contempt for longstanding allies and a belief that force alone matters in international affairs. The path forward, as Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney argued in Davos, lies in midsize democracies banding together to preserve what remains of the postwar order.

item.title: Trump Has Killed American Deterrence
item.description: Deterrence fails not only when threats to act or retaliate lack credibility, but when the absence of credibility tempts adversaries into recklessness. A leader like Donald Trump, who cannot commit and is disloyal to even his closest allies, is not merely ineffective; he is dangerous because he tempts adversaries to act recklessly.

item.title: Trump’s War Against the States
item.description: The killing of two US citizens by federal immigration officers marks a grim turning point in President Donald Trump’s efforts to militarize domestic law enforcement. The events in Minneapolis underscore the dangers of unchecked executive power, as weakened courts and a compliant Congress leave states exposed to federal coercion.

item.title: Trump’s American Titanic
item.description: Donald Trump’s bullying of allies and fallacious arguments have put the US on a collision course with disaster, winning only rare plaudits, notably from the likes of Vladimir Putin. The rest of the world is reorienting itself away from the United States, making an orderly dash for the life rafts that will carry them to dry land together.

item.title: The Promise of a Middle-Power Alliance
item.description: In his landmark Davos speech, Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney urged the world’s middle powers to band together, or else risk being dominated by the United States and China. To succeed, they must strengthen trade ties, develop autonomous supply chains, and implement meaningful institutional reforms.

item.title: Is Affluence a Barrier to Living Well?
item.description: In a new book, Brink Lindsey argues that wealthy liberal democracies have essentially solved the problem of material provision and are now experiencing a nervous breakdown. But humans have always struggled with the challenge of living well and wisely.

item.title: What Would a Bardella Presidency Mean For France?
item.description: National Rally’s Jordan Bardella has emerged as the frontrunner in France’s presidential race, confronting the European Union with the prospect of a far-right Euroskeptic in the Elysée. Yet Bardella appears less intent on dismantling the EU than on exploiting its existing arrangements, which already work to France’s advantage.

item.title: Trump’s Waterloo?
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s second term has been defined by unilateralism, militarism, and lawlessness, pushing constitutional checks and balances to their limits. His intervention in Venezuela could be the point at which his governing style collides with reality, alienating his base and accelerating his political decline.

item.title: Trump Has Condemned Europe to Success
item.description: To survive in a dangerous new world, the European Union, established as an antidote to power politics, must contradict the very principle on which it was founded by becoming a superpower in its own right. Fortunately, it already has all the assets it needs in order to do so.

item.title: Building a Middle-Power World Order
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney is right to warn that the old global order has ruptured, and that middle powers must now come together to advance shared interests. They can do so by embracing the principles guiding narrower multilateral arrangements that have proved more effective than many realize.

item.title: Ukraine Is Essential to Europe’s Post-American Defense
item.description: Given the growing doubts about American security guarantees, Ukraine is now the first and by far most effective line of defense for Europe. It should therefore be recognized as a key element of Europe’s defense perimeter, with access to European funding, technology, networks, and intelligence.

item.title: America’s Year of Self-Destruction
item.description: The United States owes its superpower status not to pure might, but to the unique combination of material advantages and Enlightenment values. With his reliance on naked power and rejection of all constraints on his authority, Donald Trump represents the opposite of everything that made the country great.

item.title: American or Chinese Exceptionalism?
item.description: Both US and Chinese leaders are guilty of personalizing the conflict-prone Sino-American relationship. Continuing down this path – particularly if Donald Trump’s degradation of American leadership becomes a permanent shift, rather than an aberration – raises the important question of which country is truly exceptional.
